questions.question_text: A network technician is helping an end user who is working on a spreadsheet for a very important client. The client can see the file on the remote share but is not able to open the document to print it. This issue is associated with which of the following OSI layers?

discussion.content:
NOT L6 - L6 deals with compression, encryption and file data types.

L7 deals with the application it SELF. cannot be opened, some issue is here. Logical thinking, answer is correct. The "file" being opened has nothing to do with compression or file types, the question doesnt ask this.

comments.content: YES, presentation layer deal with encryption and compression.

discussion.content: its not application Layer the correct answer is layer 6 Presentation layer I'm 100% sure
in application layer is what you see
Is it application simply because he can't open the file?

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct port number for NTP?

discussion.content:
NTP uses UDP port 123 and is the most correct answer.
SMTP uses TCP port 25.
TFTP uses UDP port 69.
SNMP uses UDP port 161.

comments.content: I have a discussion going with someone who stated that "no one" uses standard port numbers anymore but always forwards all standard ports to others for the sake of security.
Let's remove the word "most" from your post, and we're good. :)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The only possible answer is port 123.
ya 123 is the correct answer and i hope i can see this kind of question on my exam.
Per Mike Meyer's book: Warm site should only take a day or 2 to bring online whereas a Hot Site should only take a few hours to bring online

momentary downtime - warm site, hot site would be up and running within moments or hours. cold site is a building or perserved location that the company owns but not configured, snapshot is a sort of backup method to upload to servers etc
the KEY WORD is "operations are immediately transitioned".....therefore.HOT site
Nevermind. Brief would mean less than day. Which is what a warm site might be. Thanks anyway!
Why isnâ€™t this a warm site? Momentary is defined as brief. A hot site has no down time I thought.
Damn this question got me, momentary downtime got me thinking it was a warm site not hot site!

questions.question_text: A flood disables the equipment in a company's server room. When implementing the disaster recovery plan, all operations are immediately transitioned to another location with momentary downtime. This is an example of a:

A user in the finance department can access the department printer and file server yet is unable to print to the marketing department's printer. A technician runs ipconfig and sees the following output:
IPv4 Address. . . . . . . . . . . : 192.168.0.101
Subnet Mask . . . . . . . . . . . : 255.255.255.0
Default Gateway . . . . . . . . . : 192.168.1.1
The technician has verified the user's PC is in the proper VLAN and sees an UP/UP status on the switchport. Which of the following is MOST likely causing the issue?

discussion.content: I think the gateway should be 192.168.0.1

The Default Gateway is wrong. The correct Default Gateway would be 192.168.0.0 due to the /24 mask. The host cant Print to to a printer in the Department (which i guess is a different subnet). But due to the fact that the host cant send to the right default gateway he cant reach the other subnet
Is it because it states the user can access the other department's printer? Eliminating answer D. The other answers does make sense. Leaving the given answer C.
Why C? What am I missing?

comments.content: IPv4 Address 192.168.0.101 Gateway supposed to be 192.168.0.1. Answer is C

choices.C: There is an incorrect default gateway on the user's PC.
choices.B: The two printers share the same IP address.
choices.D: The ARP table on the switch has not been cleared.
choices.A: The user's IP is the broadcast address.

questions.question_text: A wireless technician needs to deploy a single 802.11 standard that supports both 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequencies with up to 40MHz channel widths. Which of the following wireless standards should the technician configure?

discussion.content: ac is only 5ghz, n is both 5ghz and 2.4ghz
